quote: I putter about the card catalogue and compose erudite trivialities.
source: Shakespeare’s Memory, published in The New Yorker on April 5, 1998
notes: Just before the quote, Professor Sörgel writes "I am now a man among men". Maybe this is true intelligence. In our quest for higher knowledge, there's no higher acknowledgement than the recognition that all is vanity, as Ecclesiastes said, and that we can joke about it. Self-derision may be the highest form of intelligence, not because it is self-deprecating, but because it crystallizes that we are all men among men. The point is not to put yourself down. The put is to see how we can all be equal and that what I work toward doesn't make me better. It just makes me different. And in my difference, I find the astute derision that brings a little gaity and levity. Let us not take ourselves too seriously for fear of missing out on this higher form of intelligence. That's how we can achieve the highest state of knowledge.

quote: Unaquæque res quantum in se est, in suo esse perseverare conatur. (Everything, in so far as it is in itself, endeavours to persist in its own being.)
source: *Ethics*, Part 3, Proposition 6
notes: The most immediate application is the "conatus" or the desire to continue to exist. It is often instinctive, such as the will to live. However, I believe there's a higher plane of consequence. For instance, one could argue that this is why sin is such a significant problem, and it's so challenging for us to overcome. Because we are flawed as individuals, we often persist in our flaws. It's easier to keep the status quo than to change.

It's not a commentary on language and more a realization that we sometimes are attracted by the idea of a thing rather than its reality.

quote: It is not down on any map; true places never are
source: Moby Dick, Chapter 12

quote: Beauty makes promises that beauty cant keep.
source: The Passenger. 2022. p. 180. Kindle Edition.
notes: The lack of punctuation on "cant" is on purpose. Bobby Western, the main character, is talking with his grandmother about the past. Shes reminiscing about "wartime " [the Second World War], and how "a lot of young people got married that might of waited otherwise. He [Western's father] liked pretty women. And she [Western's mother] was the prettiest." Then the grandmother explains how beauty served neither of them well.

quote: Suffering is a part of the human condition and must be borne. But misery is a choice.
source: The Passenger. 2022. p. 348. Kindle Edition.
notes: In, The Passenger, the main character, Robert Western, receives a letter from John Sheddan, who is now dead. Bob hadn't learned about his passing and read the letter after his friend had been buried. The letter is dated about two months before Bob reading it. John knew he was not long for this world and talked a lot about how natural death is and how resolute he is about the whole thing.

quote: Wherever you debark was the train’s destination all along. I’ve studied much and learned little.
source: The Passenger. 2022. p. 348. Kindle Edition.
notes: Debarking is an allegory for death. There is a certain fatality to it. We may fight it. We may delay it. But where we end up is the destination. There is a certain pessimism in this approach, but it is not without reason. Sometimes, we do everything we can to avoid it only to meet death where we thought we were running away from.

quote: More time would change nothing and that which you are poised to relinquish forever almost certainly was never what you thought it to be in the first place.
source: The Passenger. 2022. p. 348. Kindle Edition.
notes: What we leave behind when we die is certainly not what we thought we would live when we started our lives. In this regard, everyone says they want more time, but more time would not change what we leave behind.

quote: A Godless life would not prepare one for a Godless death.
source: The Passenger (p. 380). (Function). Kindle Edition.

quote: for his life was never anything more than a present moment always vanishing; and now it is over.
source: The Vanity of Existence. The Essays Of Arthur Schopenhauer: Studies In Pessimism. 1913. Translated by T. Bailey Saunders.
notes:
Here, Schopenhauer talks about the fleeting life of man that is never happy, always looking for something more, "seldom attains his goal", is disappointed if he does, and ends in death no matter what. It's a great characterization of pessimism.
[November 5, 2025] There might be a way to apply this concept of the fleeting present to help with "Wanderin Minds". In his podcast "Rythms of Focus" (episode published on October 2, 2025 entitled ADHD and the Nature of Time), Kourosh Dini, MD, explains the "Lighthouse Technique". When one has an appointment in an hour, instead of trying to fill that hour, the Lighthouse Technique only fills 25% of that time and makes affordances for transitions. We may not complete the task, but it will be ready for us when we start again. If we see the present as fleeting, then our attitude should be to guide our presents, not shackle them. By realizing that life is just a series of vanishing presents, we let go of the mindset that we must finish a task and instead recognize that we are just trying to bring meaning to fleeting moments.
references: [The Essays of Arthur Schopenhauer: Studies in Pessimism, by Arthur Schopenhauer](http://linkwarden.civera.ca:3000/preserved/31?format=4)

quote: All crime is vulgar, just as all vulgarity is crime.
source: The Picture of Dorian Gray: The Original 1890 Edition (A Oscar Wilde Classics) (p. 224). (Function). Kindle Edition.

Low people do it because they can't get "sensations" any other way. Besides the direct classist tone, it's a way to ensure the rich are never guilty, regardless of what they do.

quote: It is the spectator, and not life, that art really mirrors.
source: The Picture of Dorian Gray: The Original 1890 Edition (A Oscar Wilde Classics). Kindle Edition.
notes: [October 22, 2025] Not sure I agree with the premise, but it is an interesting take. If beauty is in the eye of the beholder, and all art is perceived by the spectator, then art doesn't reflect an objective version of reality but only a reality filtered by the perception of the spectator.

quote: Men marry because they are tired; women, because they are curious: both are disappointed.
source: The Picture of Dorian Gray: The Original 1890 Edition (A Oscar Wilde Classics). Kindle Edition.

quote: It is only the intellectually lost who ever argue.
source: The Picture of Dorian Gray: The Original 1890 Edition (A Oscar Wilde Classics). Kindle Edition.
notes: [October 24, 2025] This pronouncement is uttered by Lord Henry Wotton (nicknamed Harry) to his friend Basil. It is condescending and aims to mark his feeling of superiority. Lord Henry ends the debate he has with Basil in an instant about why Basil should show the picture of Dorian Gray. Yet it is also so very true.

quote: Not everything that is faced can be changed. But nothing can be changed until it is faced.
source: The New York Times, Section: The New York Times Book Review, As Much Truth As One Can Bear by James Baldwin. 1962 January 14. Last paragraph.

quote: People are very fond of giving away what they need most themselves. It is what I call the depth of generosity.
source: The Picture of Dorian Gray: The Original 1890 Edition (A Oscar Wilde Classics) (p. 57). (Function). Kindle Edition.
notes: The sentence is pronounced by Lord Henry as a jest when Dorian Gray tells him that Basil gives him good advice. It's extremely ironic and implies that Basil is the one who really needs advice, not the one giving it. It's also a commentary on the human condition. Many poor societies are much more giving than rich ones. Many who lack education are trying to convince someone they are right. It's a human paradox.

quote: Style is a very simple matter; it is all rhythm. Once you get that, you can’t use the wrong words.
source: The letters of Virginia Woolf : volume III, 1923-1928. New York : Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Page 247
notes: [November 6, 2025]The full quote is "Style is a very simple matter; it is all rhythm. Once you get that, you can’t use the wrong words. But on the other hand here am I sitting after half the morning, crammed with ideas, and visions, and so on, and can’t dislodge them, for lack of the right rhythm. Now this is very profound, what rhythm is, and goes far deeper than words. A sight, an emotion, creates this wave in the mind, long before it makes words to fit it; and in writing (such is my present belief) one has to recapture this, and set this working (which has nothing apparently to do with words) and then, as it breaks and tumbles in the mind, it makes words to fit it: But no doubt I shall think differently next year."
references: [The letters of Virginia Woolf : volume III, 1923-1928](https://archive.org/details/lettersofvirgini00nico/lettersofvirgini00nico)

quote: We only wonder why a man has to be ill before he can be accessible to a truth of this kind.

notes: [November 12, 2025]The original quote is "When in his heightened selt-criticism he describes himself as petty, egoistic dishonest, lacking in independence, one whose sole aim has beer to hide the weaknesses of his own nature, it may be, so far as we know, that he has come pretty near to understanding him-self; we only wonder why a man has to be ill before he can be accessible to a truth of this kind." Freud marvels that it sometimes takes a man to fall deeply ill psychologically to be truly honest about who he really is.
